docs.snippet: A new wave of analysts wants to do away with contrived narratives. But if not for the stories, why watch?...
docs.lead_paragraph: A new wave of analysts wants to do away with contrived narratives. But if not for the stories, why watch?
docs.abstract: Jay Caspian Kang On Sports column argues rational drive to do away with sweeping, if manufactured, sports narratives in favor of hard statistics and analysis misses appeal of sports for majority of fans; holds sight of men and women chasing ball around field offers emotional and existential lessons that numbers cannot.

headline.main: How Do You Tell a Better Story in Sports?
headline.print_headline: How Do You Tell a Better Story in Sports?

docs.snippet: Ortiz hit a two-run homer, and Jackie Bradley Jr. added a solo shot in a 3-2 victory....

docs.snippet: Bolt claimed gold in the 100 meters for the third Summer Olympics in a row, reaffirming his title as the world’s fastest man while beating an aging rival cast as his opposite....
docs.lead_paragraph: Bolt claimed gold in the 100 meters for the third Summer Olympics in a row, reaffirming his title as the world’s fastest man while beating an aging rival cast as his opposite.
docs.abstract: Michael Powell Sports of the Times column reflects on Usain Bolt winning gold in 100 meters at Rio Olympics, third straight Summer Olympics in row in which he has won event; notes Bolt's longstanding rivalry with American Justin Gatlin, who won silver; says Bolt's planned retirement from sport will mark end of era.

headline.main: Usain Bolt’s Showdown With Justin Gatlin Carries a Sense of History’s Passing
headline.print_headline: Titans Clash Before Time Catches Up

docs.snippet: Like the opulent opera house in Manaus, which was built by rubber barons and fell into disuse, the costly Arena da Amazônia is providing little benefit....
docs.lead_paragraph: Like the opulent opera house in Manaus, which was built by rubber barons and fell into disuse, the costly Arena da Amazônia is providing little benefit.
docs.abstract: Michael Powell Sports of The Times column argues Arena da Amazonia in Manaus, Brazil, which was built for 2014 soccer World Cup but now sits mostly unused except for scattered 2016 Olympic matches, has not benefited needy residents of city surrounded by Amazon rain forest.

headline.main: In the Brazilian Rain Forest, ‘a White Elephant, a Big One’
headline.print_headline: In the Brazilian Rain Forest, ‘a White Elephant, a Big One’
